case_name: Associated Industries P Ltd. v. Regional Provident-Fund Commissioner

facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 324 of 1962 was filed.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE, JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 324 of 1962.

facts.text: Appeal from judgment and decree dated August 8, 1960 of the Kerala High Court in O. P. No. 97 of 1953.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal from the judgment and decree dated August 8, 1960 of the Kerala High Court, in O. P. No. 97 of 1953.

facts.text: Judgment delivered on April 9, 1963 by GAJENDRAGADKAR J.

anchor.surface_text: 1963. April 9. The judgment of the Court was delivered by GAjENDRAGADKAR J.

facts.text: Appellant is Associated Industries Pvt. Ltd., Quilon, running a tile factory and engineering works.

anchor.surface_text: the factory run by the appellant, the Associated Industries  P  Ltd., Qulion, falls within s. 1  3  of the employees Provident Funds Act, 1952

facts.text: Tile factory began in July 1943.

anchor.surface_text: The tile factory began its career in July, 1943, and the engineering works in September, 1950.

facts.text: Engineering works began in September 1950.

anchor.surface_text: The tile factory began its career in July, 1943, and the engineering works in September, 1950.

facts.text: Tile factory and engineering works are separate and distinct industries on same premises, common ground.

anchor.surface_text: It is companymon ground that these two industries are separate and distinct and that they are carried on by the same Company and on the same premises.

facts.text: Licence under Factories Act 1948 issued for entire premises as one factory.

anchor.surface_text: It is also companymon ground that a licence issued under the Factories Act, 1948, has been issued to the appellant for the entire premises

facts.text: Regional Provident-Fund Commissioner intimated appellant on March 10, 1953 that Act applies and to deposit contributions.

anchor.surface_text: It appears that the respondent, the Regional Provident-Fund Commissioner, Vanchiyoor, Trivandrum, intimated to the appellant on March 10, 1953, that the Act

facts.text: Same requisition repeated on March 25, 1953 and April 24, 1953.

anchor.surface_text: The same requisition was repeated on March 25, 1953 and April 24, 1953.

facts.text: Appellant disputed applicability and refused to comply.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant disputed the companymon rectness of the view taken by the respondent that the appellants factory fell under the purview of the Act

facts.text: Respondent wrote on June 16, 1953 threatening action if no compliance.

anchor.surface_text: Thereupon, the respondent wrote to the appellant on June 16, 1953 informing it that appropriate action would be taken

facts.text: Appellant filed writ petition O.P. No. 97/1953 in Kerala High Court for certiorari quashing notices.

anchor.surface_text: At this stage, the appellant moved the High Court of Kerala by a writ petition  O. P. No. 97/1953  in which it claimed a writ of certiorari

facts.text: High Court rejected appellant's contention that factory not under s.1(3).

anchor.surface_text: The High Court has rejected this contention. Then it was urged before the High Court on behalf of the appellant

facts.text: High Court rejected argument that notices retrospective and illegal.

anchor.surface_text: This argument was also rejected by the High Court.

facts.text: Respondent conceded not to collect employees' share for relevant period from appellant.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court noticed the fact that it had been conceded by the respondent that he did not propose to collect the employees share

facts.text: High Court dismissed writ petition with costs.

anchor.surface_text: On these findings, the writ petition filed by the appellant was dismissed with costs

facts.text: High Court granted certificate for appeal to Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: It is against this order that the appellant has come to this Court with a certificate granted by the High Court.

facts.text: Engineering industry employs 24 workers.

anchor.surface_text: Mr. Pai attempted to argue that though engineering industry run by the appellants factory falls under Sch. I,it employs only 24 workers

facts.text: Tiles industry employs more than 50 workers.

anchor.surface_text: whereas the tiles industry employs more than 50.

facts.text: Subsequent to High Court decision, tiles industry included in Schedule I.

anchor.surface_text: We ought to add that Mr. Pai conceded that subsequent to the decision of the appellants writ petition in the High Court, the tiles industry

facts.text: Factory licensed under Factories Act as one factory.

anchor.surface_text: and it is under this licence that the said premises arc allowed to be used as one factory under the said Act

facts.text: Numerical requirement reduced to 20 by Amending Act of 1960.

anchor.surface_text: the numerical requirement of 50 has been reduced to 20 by an Amending Act of 1960.

facts.text: Appellant claimed factory not an establishment under s.1(3) of the Act.

anchor.surface_text: The main contention raised by the appellant before the High Court was that the appellants factory was not an establishment

facts.text: Two industries independent, so s.1(3)(a) applies if one in Sch I.

anchor.surface_text: If the tiles industry and the engineering industry are independent of each other, then no question arises as to which is principal
the factory run by the appellant, the Associated Industries  P  Ltd., Qulion, falls within s. 1  3  of the employees Provident Funds Act, 1952  No. 19 of 1952   hereinafter called the Act .

concepts.interpretation: Applies to factories engaged in any industry in Schedule I with 50 or more employees total, including composite factories where at least one independent industry falls under Schedule I.
concepts.unlisted_description: Section 1(3) of Employees' Provident Funds Act, 1952 defining applicability to establishments.

anchor.surface_text: Section 1  3   a  provides, inter alia, that subject to the provisions companytained in s. 16, the Act applies to every-establishment which is a factory engaged in any industry specified in Schedule I

concepts.interpretation: Not confined to factories exclusively engaged in scheduled industries; covers composite factories with multiple independent industries if one is in Sch. I and numerical test met for whole factory.
concepts.unlisted_description: Sub-section specifying application to factories in Sch. I industries.

anchor.surface_text: Section  2   g  A.1,R.  1962  B.C. 1536. defines a factory as meaning any premises, including the precincts thereof, in any part of which a manufacturing process is being carried on

concepts.interpretation: Has comprehensive meaning including premises where manufacturing process carried on; used to determine factory for s.1(3)(a).

concepts.interpretation: Includes industries in Sch. I or added by notification.

anchor.surface_text: If a factory runs more industries than one, one of which is the primary and the dominant industry and the others are its feeders and can be regarded as subsidiary, minor, or incidental industries in that sense, then the character of the dominant and primary industry will determine

concepts.interpretation: For composite factories, if one dominant/primary industry and others subsidiary/feeders, dominant determines applicability; if independent industries, applies if any one in Sch. I.

concepts.unlisted_description: Judge-made test to determine if multi-industry factory falls under EPF Act based on independence vs. subsidiary nature.

issues.text: whether the factory run by the appellant, the Associated Industries P Ltd., Quilon, falls within s. 1(3) of the employees Provident Funds Act, 1952

anchor.surface_text: the factory run by the appellant, the Associated Industries  P  Ltd., Qulion, falls within s. 1  3  of the employees Provident Funds Act, 1952  No. 19 of 1952   hereinafter called the Act .

issues.text: whether the appellants factory was not an establishment to which s. 1(3) of the Act applied

anchor.surface_text: The main contention raised by the appellant before the High Court was that the appellants factory was not an establishment to which s. 1  3  of the Act applied.

issues.text: whether the effect of the notices served on the appellant by the respondent was retrospective in character and the said notices were illegal

anchor.surface_text: Then it was urged before the High Court on behalf of the appellant that the effect of the notices served on the appellant by the respondent was retrospective in character and it was urged that the said notices were illegal.

issues.text: whether since for the relevant period the employees had not made their contributions, it would be inequitable to enforce the notices against the appellant

anchor.surface_text: I he appellant further contended before the High Court that since for the relevant period the employees had not made their contributions, it would be inequitable to enforce the notices against the appellant.

whether if the appellants factory is treated as falling under s. 1(3)(a), a distinction should be made in the different industries run by the factory for the purpose of calculating the contribution of the employer to the Provident Fund

anchor.surface_text: In that case, this Court was dealing with the cases of Shree Krishna Metal Manufacturing Co., and Oudh Sugar Mills Ltd. The Metal Company carried on four

arguments.claim: In Oudh Sugar Mills case, feeder activity to primary industry outside Sch. I meant factory outside s.1(3)(a)

anchor.surface_text: On the other hand, the case of the Oudh Sugar Mills stood on a different basis. The primary activity of the mills was the manufacture of hydrogenated vegetable

arguments.claim: High Court rightly rejected that factory does not attract s.1(3)(a)

anchor.surface_text: Therefore, in our opinion, the High Court was plainly right in rejecting the appellants case that its factory did number attract the provisions of s. 1  3   a

holdings.text: Section 1(3)(a) of the Employees' Provident Funds Act, 1952 applies to every factory engaged in any industry specified in Schedule I in which 50 or more persons are employed, and this includes composite factories running multiple industries where at least one such industry falls under Schedule I and the numerical test is satisfied for the factory as a whole.

anchor.surface_text: In the case of the Regional Provident Fund Commissioner, Bombay,  1 this Court has held that s. 1  3   a  does number lend itself to the companystruction that it is

holdings.reasoning_summary: Follows and applies precedent from Regional Provident Fund Commissioner v. Shree Krishna Metal Mfg. Co., rejecting exclusive engagement requirement and holding numerical test applies to factory not individual industry.

holdings.text: The true legal position under s.1(3)(a) for factories running multiple industries is: applies if one industry in Sch. I; if multiple all in Sch. I; if one dominant/primary in Sch. I with subsidiaries not; does not if dominant not in Sch. I but subsidiaries are; applies if multiple independent industries with at least one in Sch. I.

anchor.surface_text: In order to make the position clear let us state the true legal position in respect of the scope of the application of s. 1  3   a  in categorical terms. If the factory carries on one industry which falls under Sch. I

holdings.reasoning_summary: Categorically states scope based on distinguishing scenarios of primary/subsidiary vs. independent industries, drawing from Shree Krishna (independent activities covered) and Oudh Sugar (feeder not covered).

holdings.text: The appellant's tile factory and engineering works are separate, distinct, and independent industries, so no question of dominant/primary arises; since engineering falls under Sch. I and total employees exceed 50, the factory falls under s.1(3)(a).

anchor.surface_text: It is companymon ground that these two industries are separate and distinct and that they are carried on by the same Company and on the same premises.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Accepts common ground on separateness; applies independent industries limb of test; rejects petitioner's dominance claim based on start date and employee numbers as irrelevant for independent industries.

holdings.text: The High Court was right in rejecting the contention that the appellant's factory does not attract s.1(3)(a).

anchor.surface_text: Therefore, in our opinion, the High Court was plainly right in rejecting the appellants case that its factory did number attract the provisions of s. 1  3   a

holdings.reasoning_summary: Affirms High Court based on above analysis and precedent.

holdings.text: The respondent's concession not to collect employees' share for relevant period is proper and fair; no substance in inequity claim.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court numbericed the fact that it had been companyceded by the respondent that he did number propose to companylect the employees share

holdings.reasoning_summary: Notes concession resolves equity concern raised by petitioner.

holdings.text: Issue of distinguishing industries for contribution rates under amended s.6 not decided as hypothetical.

anchor.surface_text: We do number propose to deal with this companytention in the present appeal. That is a matter which may well have to be decided by the respondent,

holdings.reasoning_summary: Declines to decide future/hypothetical complication for administrative authority.
